        #include <stdio.h>
        #include <stdlib.h>
        #include <string.h>

        int main() {
            // Step1: read the input for the first program
            int N;
            scanf("%d", &N);
            int *A = (int*)malloc(N * sizeof(int));
            for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
                scanf("%d", &A[i]);
            }

            // First program's logic
            int mn = N+1, mx = -1;
            for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
                if (i+1 != A[i]) {
                    if (i < mn) mn = i;
                    if (i > mx) mx = i;
                }
            }

            char S[100]; // We'll use a buffer to hold the string for the first program's output (without newline)

            if (mx == -1) {
                strcpy(S, "0 0"); // This is 3 characters: '0',' ','0'
            } else {
                // Format the two integers: mn+1 and mx+1
                sprintf(S, "%d %d", mn+1, mx+1); // This writes the string without newline
            }

            // Now, S holds the string that the first program would output (without the newline)

            // Step2: second program's logic on the string S
            int num_g = 0, num_p = 0, score = 0;
            int len = strlen(S);
            for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
                char c = S[i];
                if (c == 'g') {
                    if (num_g - num_p > 0) {
                        score += 1;
                        num_p += 1;
                    } else {
                        num_g += 1;
                    }
                } else if (c == 'p') {
                    if (num_g - num_p > 0) {
                        num_p += 1;
                    } else {
                        score -= 1;
                        num_g += 1;
                    }
                }
                // else: do nothing
            }

            // Step3: third program's logic
            int n = score;   // which is 0
            int result = (n * 2 + 1) / 3; // integer division: 1/3 -> 0

            printf("%d\n", result);

            free(A);
            return 0;
        }

        #include <stdio.h>
        #include <stdlib.h>
        #include <string.h>

        int main() {
            int N;
            scanf("%d", &N);
            int *A = (int *)malloc(N * sizeof(int));
            for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
                scanf("%d", &A[i]);
            }

            // First program logic
            int mn = N + 1;
            int mx = -1;
            for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
                if (i + 1 != A[i]) {
                    if (i < mn) {
                        mn = i;
                    }
                    if (i > mx) {
                        mx = i;
                    }
                }
            }

            char S[100];
            if (mx == -1) {
                strcpy(S, "0 0");
            } else {
                sprintf(S, "%d %d", mn+1, mx+1);
            }

            // Now simulate the second program on S
            int num_g = 0, num_p = 0, score = 0;
            for (int i = 0; S[i] != '\0'; i++) {
                char c = S[i];
                if (c == 'g') {
                    if (num_g > num_p) { // equivalent to num_g - num_p > 0
                        score++;
                        num_p++;
                    } else {
                        num_g++;
                    }
                } else if (c == 'p') {
                    if (num_g > num_p) {
                        num_p++;
                    } else {
                        score--;
                        num_g++;
                    }
                }
            }

            // Third program
            int n = score;
            int result = (n * 2 + 1) / 3; // integer division truncates toward zero? In C, for positive it's floor. But note: (0*2+1)=1, 1/3=0.

            printf("%d\n", result);

            free(A);
            return 0;
        }

   However, note: the third program in Python: 
        print((n * 2 + 1) // 3) 
        In Python, integer division for nonnegative numbers is the same as in C (truncated toward zero? actually, in Python it's floor division, but for nonnegative it's the same as truncation in C for positive).

        For n=0: (0*2+1)=1, then 1//3 in Python is 0. In C: 1/3 is 0 (for integer division).

   So it's the same.

        In Python: (n*2+1)//3 
        In C: (n*2+1)/3   -> but if n is negative, then the division in C truncates toward zero, but in Python floors?
